excellent_study: maybe
missing_something_major: Individual responses, take into account tree ring limitations and sampling, interesting use of tree ring data at large scale, the path analyses confounds processes which is totally fixable
notes: NA

study_scale: 1 common garden, 24 provenances from all over Canada
growth_metric: growth anomalies (e.g. Spring frost ring, late frost ring, wood density fluctuations, etc.)
authorsthink_evidence_gslbygrowth: unsure. the authors claim provenances from different areas showed very contrasting anomalies depending of heir origin. Pops from warmer showed more latewood anomalies consistent with more extensive use of growing season
excellent_study: no
missing_something_major: interesting idea of using wood anomalies. Proves adaptation (or maladaptation) by provenances across the range. Cool provenance study. Proves nothing related to GSL
notes: NA

ifyouthink_no_why: they lump all effects of climate change  (including ""growing season length, net N mineralization,  N fixation"" together in their reporting so it is difficult to pull out only effects of increased GSL)
ifyes_whichexternal: N deposition, climate, gsl, CO2 fertilization
excellent_study: not excellent but interesting modelling study
notes:
interannual variations in the C balance 
of Canada's forests dominated by climate variability, whereas over the long term the effects of N  deposition and CO2 fertilization have accumulated to become substantial. During 1895-1996, N deposition was the largest contributor to the nondisturbance effects with a total  contribution of-42%, followed by climate change at -34% and CO2 fertilization at -19% (Table 2)

species_list: Betula pubescens, Picea abies,  Pinus sylvestris(for growth)
study_scale: tree rings from cores collected from 11 different sites in high latitude and treeline locations in northern Sweden; n per species was 3,4,10, respectively)
excellent_study: no. they measured phenology and compared it to tree ring data, but because they 1) used different species across phenology and tree ring components; and 2) did not use raw ring widths (instead using detrended indices that were correlated with different month's temperatures, rather than growing season length)
missing_something_major: they analyzed trends in start vs end of growing season separately, and these were analyzed separately from tree ring data. If these data had been integrated in a different way, the authors could have addressed our question

species_list: Aesculus hippocastanum, Betula pendula, Fagus sylvativa, Larix decidua, Quercus robur, Sorbus aucuparia
study_scale: tested the degree to which timing of autumn senescence (from long-term obs data in PEP) is determined by preceding seasonal productivity (estimated from a  photosynthesis model)
study_type: continental scale obs phenology with model
authorsthink_evidence_gslbygrowth: no (or atleast, its weaker than others think)
authorsthink_ALTteststatistic:: R2, RMSE, Slope of their PIA model vs. other common models that are more focused on growing season length only
ifyes_whichexternal: elevated carbon dioxide, temperature, light, water stress
excellent_study: interesting!
missing_something_major: I'm not sure about assumptions of photosynthesis modelâ€¦

authorsthink_ALTteststatistic:: they test for relationship between photosynthesis and senescence date only (not GSL)
ifyouthink_no_why: not sure how photosynthesis relates to growth
excellent_study: interesting!
missing_something_major: but how does leaf- and plant-level photosynthesis relate to overall growth/biomass?

authorsthink_ALTteststatistic:: they test for relationship between photosynthesis and senescence date only (not GSL)
ifyouthink_no_why: how does early season phenology and thus GSL relate this?
authorsfoundevidencefor_externalfactors: yes- treatments that enhanced growingseason photosynthesis (whether by CO2 entirchment or temperature increase )caused advances in autumn senescence
excellent_study: interesting!
missing_something_major: but how does leaf- and plant-level photosynthesis relate to overall growth/biomass?

study_scale: 35 provenances across Canada (full species range), 2 common gardens southern canada
authorsthink_ALTteststatistic:: correlation between height growth duration and height
excellent_study: no
missing_something_major: decent stats/clarity
notes:
growth_metric: subset of individuals harvested for biomass - very hard to tell which they meant throughout when referencing growth especially in the difference between sites.   authorsthink_evidence_gslbygrowth: so this was weird, height was correlated with duration of height growth
But biomass growth was highest at the site with fewer GDD and shorter height growth duration.   authorsthink_teststatistic: relationship between GDD and biomass was really a difference between the 2 gardens not directly attributed to GDD

excellent_study: no
missing_something_major: NA

excellent_study: no
missing_something_major: weirdly small sample size even for what they did

species_list: Carya, Fraxinus, Quercus, Acer, Betula, Fagus, Liriodendron, Magnolia, Nyssa, Populus
rep_number: n = 119 trees from 2011 to 2020 for HF; 321 trees from 1998 to 2003
teststatistic_where: there was no consistent lengthening of Lpgs (Fig. 1 and Extended Data Figs. 3 and 4)
excellent_study: Sadly no, because they never actually test the GSL to growth link.
notes: Did not correlate phenology and growth; correlated something like spring phenology sensitivity (they call it CTW, see bottom right pg 554) with growth (multiple metrics)

species_list: Carya, Fraxinus, Quercus, Acer, Betula, Fagus, Liriodendron, Magnolia, Nyssa, Populus
excellent_study: See other row of data for this paper
notes: This is followup to their phenology x dendrometer part of the paper, they used tree rings to look at lots of correlations.

species_list: Picea abies, Pinus sylvestris, Abies alba, Fagus sylvatica, Fraxinus excelsior, Quercus petraea, Quercus pubescens
study_scale: TreeNet; 47 sites and 8 years of data
teststatistic_where: Thus, phenology hardly contributed to explain the inter-annual variation in annual growth, whereas growth activity, particularly N daysgrowth, turned out to be the most important predictor in the LMM, explaining 65% to 88% of the inter- annual variation (Table S3, Figure S8).
ifyouthink_no_why: they use wood growth phenology to measure growth phenology â€¦is this our questiion?
ifyes_whichendogenous: Species including ring vs. diffuse porous
excellent_study: This is a very important study for us as they have data on lots of our surrounding questions, but their 'dredge' approach the analyses is diffiucult to interpret.
missing_something_major: leaf phenology
notes: They find that they number of days plants grow (growth>0) is more related to growth than the end-start dates of growth. This feels more tautilogical than they admit.

study_level: within individuals for < 1 year (April to October 2018)
teststatistic_where: xylem production timing x xylem production â€¦ I think
ifyouthink_no_why: focused on xylem production, very low sample size
ifyes_whichendogenous: They looked at lots of 'anatomical features' and lots about early/latewood â€¦ maybe that counts?
missing_something_major: More data people
notes: Though I realize these data are painstaking to collect

study_scale: upper and lower treeline in two regions: Tebetian plateau and Mojave Desert
excellent_study: no, no link to leaf phenology and more climatic characterization of the GS

study_scale: 2 forests, one in Spain, one in Russia
excellent_study: yes, not extraordinary but they combine growth and phenology
missing_something_major: a measure for the end of the GS. For one species they measure leaf fall which is something but not even clear to me how this is measured in Pines and how important that is!
notes: NA

ifyes_whichexternal: spring temperature mainly, but also elevation, precipication (they also looked at land cover and other climate variables)
excellent_study: The study didn't really look at direct metrics of growth or growing season so not really. They didn't explicitly look at growing season length but did examine spring temp and productivty. I though it was cool that they looked at productivity in spring but also in summer and fall separatelt and were able to find lags that were somewhat explained by elevation and precipiation

study_scale: 3 sites along elevational gradient and 80 individuals
gsl_start_metric: snow meltout and snow free growing degree days
excellent_study: Maybe. They didnâ€™t explicitly look at GSL, but they did use snow melt out and snow free growing degree days as a proxy. If we believe this is a good proxy for start of growing season for this shrub then the paper was good and looked at variation in response to cliamte across elevations too. I just wish they had explicitly also looked at leaf phenology to describe growing season onset

study_scale: 9 populations along an elevational gradient of 1500 m in the French
study_level: across sites/populations across years within individuals
ifyouthink_no_why: there is no correlation between longer growing seasons and increased ring width
excellent_study: pretty close - it would be great if they had more species and across more locations
missing_something_major: no
notes: they found no relationship between phenology and radial growth
notes_specific_columns: but they found that higher temps at higher elevations lead to increased radial growth, whereas higher temps at lower elevations decreased growth, likely due to water availability
